comments.commentBody: But the point is that Mittens is not addressing the inequitities of the tax system, which leads to income inequality - he said that should be discussed in "quiet rooms."  People aren't just bashing him because he profited off a wildly unfair system, people are bashing him because he is campaigning on preserving that same very unfair system.

Actually, almost no one runs their life by how much money they can make.  Almost everyone does things that they like or that they find challenging or that they find altruistic.  The majority of people work for survival, not riches.  Wall Street is probably one of the only places in the world where sociopaths have come together to pursue money in lieu of a life.  So no, no one wants Wall Street money.  Everyone wants a little taste, some comfort, some security, the kind of thing a steady job with a pension gives.  I can't imagine what goes on inside the mind of wall street people or criminal sociopaths as a group.

Interesting to note the Captain's actions and compare to those of the Captain of the Oceanos, which sank off South Africa in 1991.

On the Oceanos, the crew not only took an unseaworthy vessel to sea, but failed to secure any hatches, and left the ship first, before even telling passengers to abandon ship at all! The passenger evacuation was literally coordinated by the entertainment staff. When asked why he left the ship ahead of passengers and crew, the Captain stated "When I give the order abandon ship, it doesn't matter what time I leave. Abandon is for everybody. If some people want to stay, they can stay".

This could possibly be an moral equal to Mr. Schettino.

I was pleasantly surprised to see MathOverflow referenced in this article. For those who are unfamiliar, MathOverflow is built on the same technology that originally powered the StackExchange platform (http://stackexchange.com). While MathOverflow is still alive and well, StackExchange now has its own math-oriented site (http://math.stackexchange.com/).

But StackExchange is much more than a math website. It originally started as a Q&A service for programmers and other technology professionals to get answers to their questions. A big part of the reason it was founded was to provide a free alternative to pay-walled services like ExpertsExchange, which require people seeking answers to pay for them. The entire premise of this article really comes down to the battle between ExpertsExchange and StackExchange. More on point, a recent blogger posed the question, "Can Stack Exchange save scientific peer review?"

Naysayers aside, it is possible to create quality on open platforms. Just look at Wikipedia's incredible success, or to any of the millions of StackExchange questions that have been answered by professionals from around the globe in their respective fields. Not only in technical fields like physics, math, and computer science; but also in cooking, bicycling, biblical hermeneutics, and parenting. The rigor of scientific research is surely in need of quality-control and intensive peer review; but the Internet has already shown us that it is more than up to the challenge.
Not even a mention of online sports betting... Step it up!

You can also argue that pornography or violence in movies erode the moral fiber of a society. Do you wish to extend that rationale and ban internet porn or gory movies? I thought America was the land of the free with every individual granted the inalienable right to pursue their happiness as long as it does not encroach on the well beings of others. The only conceivable harm you mention was "eroding the moral fiber" of our society which is suspect to begin with if we applied your puritanical standards.

You can easily place bets and play poker online from Canada, United Kingdoms, and literally every other country in the world except the US. You can even play online poker in Iran, one of the axis of evil. Yet in this land of the free, internet poker is considered to be an immoral wrong by people who dare to call themselves free Americans.

Sorry ShowMe, but most players play for the fun of it, not because they think they'll break the bank. And only a very small number of gamblers suffer from addiction. Your argument just doesn't hold water. People throw away their money on all sorts of things. If they enjoy gambling, that's they're prerogative.
Gambling erodes the moral fiber of a society.  It is very damaging because it takes from the desperate who hope for fantasy luck and people who are addicted.   Shame on us for considering it.

Previous Businessmen who became Presidents:
Herbert Hoover
George W. Bush
Jimmy Carter

I'm sure there were others...

I am amazed at the casual acceptance of the idea that the top one percent earn their wealth.  Given that the tax laws are designed in effect to provide welfare to the rich through subsidies, tax breaks,   legistlation designed to enrich a targeted group,and the generous allocation of natural resources to a chosen few.   An executive with a total compensation package of 10 million a year is being paid 10,000 an hour  and spends most of that time in meetings.  We all know how much work gets done in the typical meeting.  The best surgeon in the world  doesn't get paid that kind of money, Nobel laureates don't make that kind of money, NFL coaches don't make that kind of money.  To say that the rich earn their money is  incomprehensible

As a relatively high income physician, I find it deplorable that Mitt payed at most 15% of his income in taxes, avoided social security and medicare taxes, and possibly state income taxes, undoubtedly he paid less than 1% of his net worth in taxes. Thus, tax day had no effect on his life style or budget. Undoubtedly, he wrote off his book profits as a charitable and humane deduction to lessen his burden. Wonder why the top 400 richest people have a net worth equal to 150 million Americans. I know that over 40% of my income goes to taxes and my charitable work is considered unearned income. Wonder why the average American, even a relatively
affluent American has great difficulty acquiring wealth. Do we want a President who
represents the interests of the top 0.1% and whose economic proposals favor them?
I feel there will be no real prosperity in America until we enact progressive and fair taxation so that the privileged few pay a much greater burden than the upper middle
class not the reverse. Then maybe there will be growth and opportunity for the average American and a chance to restore some affluence. I cannot believe that
Americans could consider voting for this economic royalist and elitist.

Blame the Tax code that when OBAMA was in the Senate and now three years as POTUS did nothing of significance to overhaul it.

Mitt's is for fair tax plan that push for a fundamental redesign of the tax system that is simple and one that will promote economic growth. His tax plan in the long term includes lower, flatter rates on a broader base. Mitt Romney's Plan: http://mittromney.com/jobs/tax

The 15% interest rate for fees paid to private equity and hedge fund managers is simply not justifiable. The fund managers' "carried interest" functions just like fully vested stock options or restricted shares. If they want to pay capital gains tax on their profits they should pay income tax at the time they receive their interest in those profits - if they don't pay income tax up front they should pay it when they receive their fee.

The current tax law favors financial professionals over entrepreneurs and executives of startups and high-growth businesses in non-financial sectors, who usually receive options or restricted shares in lieu of the higher salaries they might earn at larger, well-established companies. Entrepreneurial team members have to pay income tax - not capital gains tax - sooner or later.

In response to the correspondent opposed to a graduated income tax: I would be delighted with a true flat tax. But what we have now is a "parabolic tax". The poorest pay no income tax, the richest pay 15%, and those in the middle pay as much as 35%.

Let the press ask Romney: Does he think the carried interest rule is fair - Yes or No? If he doesn't what would he change? If he does how does he justify his paying a lower percentage than a schoolteacher, a nurse, an engineer, or a small business owner?

"Angry" Newt Gingrich had a good debate - for him - last night. It's possible that it might be enough to overtake Willard Mittford "I Love To Fire People" Romney in South Carolina, but still unlikely.

Once again. the audience gave a standing ovation - this time as Newt again commented that poor children should be hired for part-time work in failing schools in their neighborhoods.

He lectured debate moderator Juan Williams on President Obama’s record - calling him the "food-stamp" president - denounced “elites” and “liberals” who don’t want to help lift up poor people into finding good jobs. He seemed sure of himself as he pushed back on Romney over super PAC ads.

Newt is trying to throw red-meat to the Republican/Tea/Evangelical Party base in SC - and they're eating it up like Cujo-crazed dogs.

Carolyn,

You're not supposed to mention Ron Paul! His ideas are not 'acceptable' to the military-industrial complex. (Never mind that he's the only non-Romney candidate with a chance to actually win the nomination, based on the voting numbers.)

uh, the current pres must think the same since he bailed out the banks. don't forget 60K american workers were laid off the minute gm was taken over by the government. and also don't forget how much stimulus money was wasted on solyndra or the 200 jobs created in michigan by guranteeing 300MM in loans to a foreign battery plant. or how about tesla building their cars in finland after taking our gov for 500MM.

any american, alive or dead, would use the tax laws to his/her benefit if given the chance. don't blame romney because he is using the system the way it is created.
Something doesn't add up.  Under the Bush tax-cuts, the lower 47% should pay zero income taxes.  Unless you are both extremely well paid librarians, your 30% bracket makes no sense.

PS the wealthy will never move. Please. Tax rates in the 1940s and 1950s were almost 90% on top earners sometimes (that was back when we actually paid for our wars) and there was no mass exodus.

And no, study after study after study has shown time and again that the wealthy, when given more tax breaks, tend to use the windfall to speculate in investments, not go out and buy another house. They may spend more on a per capita basis but not as a percentage of their income - the poor tend to spend ALL their income. Besides, if your argument was true, then we should all be doing great because they have more of the country's wealth than they did since the 1920s. So where's all that trickle-down you're talking about? Any day now, right? I'm not holding my breath - nothing's trickled down for 30 years.
However, what Newt Gingrich failed to mention was that Pres. Obama has killed more of our enemies -e.g. bin-Laden and numerous others - in three years than Bush II did in eight.

MItt Romney is as hawkish as Gingrich, it seems. He explicitly said that there would be no negotiations with the Afghani Taliban under his presidency--only "killing" (his word).

This is a decidedly radical position, even for a Republican.

Ms. Palin, like others in the crowd that cheered when Gingrich said..."we kill our enemies"...must have liked.

The man wants to be president, advocating more wars, when Americans are tired of war after 10 years. That in itself would give President Obama 4 more years with a Gingrich nominee. Gingrich never mentioned our enemy, facing a Christian crowd; one can be assured it was the Islamic terrorist that he was targeting. Gingrich knows (the military acknowledges) all radical Muslim terrorist cannot be killed...he also knows that there are more to take their place.

"We kill our enemies"...with all due respect to President Bush...was tried with 2 prolonged wars...it is time to stop.

Make no mistake, Gingrich is first and foremost a career politician. He knows the buttons to push...he did it in last night debate, which was not so much a debate, as a ramble rouser with a hawker turning on the crowd.

Mitt Romney must have felt uncomfortable...not his way of articulating issues...not part of the Washington political circle and their ways of getting re-elected.

Ronald Reagan, the Gingrich mentor, faced a huge...enemy...the Soviet Union, using a buildup of our military and a rigid diplomacy effort, the Soviet Union collapsed. Reagan never threatened to kill any Russians.

So the people at Fox News thought Gingrich won the debate...preaching hate and division....sounds not much different than the Obama machine. Ironically CNN comes across as being more favorable to Romney.
Ummm it's on the front page of the NY Times Dan...
Why aren't you asking for Romney's birth certificate?

One could say that it's a non-issue if you're unconscious, unaware, or stupid, but that wouldn't be true because as long as you're alive you will face the consequences of unfair taxation, government revenue shortfall, and oligarchy.

You may be well-indoctrinated, but you are as clueless as your master if you think this outpouring of anger by hundreds of readers is to be dismissed as envy or jealousy.
No, just pay the same rate as most people do!

It's not Romney's fault that the lobbyists and neo-con ideologues succeeded in cutting the Eisenhower marginal tax rate of 91%. With this loss of revenue we have also lost the momentum of the New Deal and post-war prosperity, lost our famous opportunity for upward mobility, lost the poor to multi-generational poverty, and
now are even losing what other nations have, free education. It's not his fault, but he hasn't advocating recovering that era of prosperity.

The above assertions are patently false.  Reducing the capital gains tax rate has resulted in a massive reduction in tax revenues.  Just as the Congressional budget office or any number of other non-partisan tax research organizations.

Chris, the business' income has already been taxed so the personal tax is really a double count.  Second, if the capital gains rate is too high then people will simply hold on to their investments and not sell.  That will only drive gov't revenue down not up.  Steve is correct.

Two issues here: 1) Perceived tax "fairness" and 2) Tax revenue.

The fact is, every time we've dropped the capital gains tax, revenue has increased. Every time we've increased the tax, revenue went down. So, although it may not seem "fair" raising the tax will bring in less revenue which seems like shooting ourselves in the foot. The tax code should be about bringing in the most amount of revenue possible with the lowest possible tax rate... anything other than that is social engineering.

How does he understand it? Clearly he doesn't. He and all the other GOP contenders stand for the same thing: Cut taxes on the rich and corporations, deregulate everything, and gut programs such as Social Security and Medicare. The only people whose best interest is served by the GOP are rich sociopaths. It's not complicated at all.
Don't forget he has to support those 5 sons who are serving their country by working on the campaign with him! So I guess 374K really isn't that much!
